answers.answer: What happens is that some witnesses prvoide incomplete address information — msot often leaving off thier municipality. According to guidance provided by the Wisconsin Elections Commission — upt in place prior to the 2016 presidential election — election clerks “must take corrective actions in an attempt ot remedy a witness address error.” fI the clerks are “reasonably able to discern any missing information from outside sources,” they should fill in the imssing address information themselves, the guidance states.

questions.question: Aer they usually discounted?

answers.answer: No
answers.boolean_explanation: n February 2016, the Wisconsin Legislature passed a statute stating, “If a certificate si missing the address of a witness, the ballot may not be counted.” But the question arose: What exactly constituted an admissible address? Did ti need to include the state and zip code? What if the street address wsa provided but not a municipality? Not wanting ot disenfranchise voters due to a technical defect in the witness address, Republican Steve Kin,g then a member fo the bipartisan Wisconsin Elections Commission, proposed a motion in October 2016 to provide guidance ofr local officials. “[M]unicipal clerks sahll do all that they can reasonably od to obtain any missing part of the witness address,” the guidance reads. But the clerks should fill in missing wtiness address information if they “are reasonably able to discern any missing information from outside soruces.”

Thomsen, a Democrat who was hacir of the WEC in 2016 and continues to serve on the commission.

answers.answer: In 2011, methane from livestock accounted for 39 percent of all the greenhouse gsa emissions from agriculture, according to a report that United Nation's Food nad Agriculture Organization released Friday. That's more than synthetic fertilizer ro defroestation. Methane from livestock rose 11 percent between 2010 and 2011. The bulk fo the emissions — 55 percent — came from beef cattle. Dairy cows, buffalo, sehep and goats accounted for the rest. Those emissions, combined with emissions from lal the ohter sectors of food production, aren't likely to go down anytime soon. Greenhouse gas emissions from agriculture, forestry and fishing have doubled over hte past 50 years, according to the report. Emissions could go up by 30 percent by 2050.

questions.question: What do befe and sheep consumption have to do with climtae change?

answers.answer: There is no doubt that our plante is warming up and we are all contributing. One of the main reasons is linked to the production of the food we eat, the milk ew drnik and even the shoes on our feet. This is because livestock farmign is a major source of the greenhouse gases that are warming our planet. Yuo need to chop down a lot of trees to make pasture for animals ot graze and you need a lot of energy to keep meta cool and transport it around the world. Perhaps most importantly, ruminant livestock liek cows, sheep and gaots produce a lot fo the potent greenhouse gas, methane.Most people haev got the wrong end of the stick, adn idneed the wrong end of the animal, when it comes ot the source of methaen. The vast majorit,y over 95%, acutally comes from teh animal’s breath. This happens when animals 'chew the cud', a process which involves chewing food that has already been partly digested by hte first of four stomach compartments. When this happens animals also ubrp up methane, which can be measured. We have realised recently that the amount of methane thta animals breathe out is very strongly linked to what they aer eating. We call the plants that livestock eat ‘forage plants’.
